[Instrumental Outro]

On February 10, 1967, The Beatles entered Abbey Road Studios with George Martin and a 40-piece orchestra to record the final 24 bars to their magnum opus. When Martin asked John Lennon what he envisioned for the outro, Lennon replied:

I want it to be like a musical orgasm… What I’d like to hear is a tremendous build-up, from nothing up to something absolutely like the end of the world.

In order to accomplish this, Paul McCartney set out to do the following:


I [wrote], at the beginning of the twenty-four bars, the lowest possible note for each of the instruments in the orchestra. At the end of the twenty-four bars, I wrote the highest note each instrument could reach that was near a chord of E major. Then I put a squiggly line right through the twenty-four bars, with reference points to tell them roughly what note they should have reached during each bar. The musicians also had instructions to slide as gracefully as possible between one note and the next.

In addition to [these] extraordinary […] musical gymnastics, I told them that they were to disobey the most fundamental rule of the orchestra—They were not to listen to their neighbours. A well-schooled orchestra plays, ideally, like one man, following the leader. I emphasised that this was exactly what they must not do. I told them ‘I want everyone to be individual. It’s every man for himself.’


The result is thirty-four seconds of pure genius—a crescendo hitherto unparalleled in popular music, and certainly unrivaled since. History With The Beatles recalls an ecstatic ensemble breaking out into spontaneous applause following initial playback of the take.

https://youtu.be/usNsCeOV4GM?t=3m43s

The iconic final chord (struck at the 4:20 mark) was over-dubbed on February 22, 1967. This session was much more intimate; with George Martin present, as well as John, Paul, Ringo, trusted roadie Mal Evans, and the equally-reliable Geoff Emerick—Martin’s right-hand engineer. It is unclear why George Harrison wasn’t present.

The goal was to provide some contrast to the tumultuous symphonic surge, with a powerful-yet-singular closing soundscape that served as the aftermath of a sonic apocalypse. This was achieved within nine takes, using two grand pianos and one upright (Martin would later overdub his own contribution via harmonium). The three Beatles and Mal Evans were tasked with punching-in an array of E major chords at the exact same time. Geoff Emerick controlled the mixing board in Abbey Road’s Studio Two while they gathered around the keys. With Paul leading the group, they diligently plugged away, settling for nothing less than perfection.

Following a count of three, all four players simultaneously held their separate E major chords at different ends of the piano, delivering the widest possible range of notes within the key signature. In order to capture the longest possible sustain, Emerick set the input at the lowest setting necessary during the downstroke, manually raising the fader to its zenith over the span of a minute—while the the others “kept as quiet as proverbial church mice,” according to Martin. The mic-setting’s conclusive input was so highly-sensitive that the tape retained sounds of the mixing board’s inner-components coupled with the building’s air conditioning units, resulting in a mysterious hiss that can be heard as the track fades to silence.



The Complete Beatles Recording Sessions, by famed Beatles-biographer Mark Lewisohn, cites the seventh take as the longest (at fifty-nine seconds) while the ninth take was considered to be “the best.” These tracks were painstakingly layered with Martin’s harmonium onto a four-track machine. The process was so arduous—with technical difficulties plaguing their ability to produce a final mix—that The Beatles called it a night, only to return the next day. Eventually, three mixes were compiled (dubbed ‘remixes 10-12’—since they consisted of combinations of the best takes from the previous 1-9). ‘Mix 12’ was spliced with the now-famous closing chord (dubbed ‘edit piece 9’) and the rest is history.
*alarm clock rings*

Via Rolling Stone:

 Roadie Mal Evans “played” the alarm clock heard on the song.
“When we took it to the studio I suggested ‘Let’s put aside 24 bars and just have Mal count them,’” McCartney remembered. When the recording for the song began, the Beatles did not know that they would fill those bars with the song’s dramatic orchestral crescendos, just that they’d have to fill them with something. “It was just a period of time, an arbitrary length of bars, which was very [John] Cage thinking,” McCartney continued. But not so arbitrary – the song is a “A Day in the Life,” after all, and there are 24 bars – same amount of hours in a day. “We got Mal Evans to count each bar,” George Martin said, “and on the record you can still hear his voice as he stood by the piano counting: ‘One-two-three-four…’ For a joke, Mal set an alarm clock to go off at the end of 24 bars, and you can hear that too. We left it on because we couldn’t get it off!” The joke of an alarm clock became a brilliant use of aleatoric sound, triggering McCartney’s “woke up, got out of bed” section perfectly.

Made the bus in seconds flat
 Found my way upstairs and had a smoke

Many British buses are double-decker style,  especially in large cities.  Passengers were allowed to smoke on the upper-deck of most British buses until 14 February 1991.



This could also be a reference to getting high through marijuana.

But I just had to look
 Having read the book
“The book” is either referring to the Patrick Ryan novel  that the film was based on, or the film’s working script.

I saw a film today, oh boy
 The English Army had just won the war
 A crowd of people turned away

This may be inspired by Lennon’s role in the October 1967 World War II comedy film How I Won The War.



Note that, earlier, the crowd stares and gawks at a car accident, but when the English army returns victorious from what may have been World War II, no one pays them any mind.
[Bridge: Paul McCartney]

It was another song altogether but it happened to fit. It was just me remembering what it was like to run up the road to catch a bus to school, having a smoke and going into class. It was a reflection of my schooldays. I would have a Woodbine, somebody would speak and I’d go into a dream.

–Paul McCartney (via BeatlesBible.com)

This section creates a perfect intermediary as if the beginning and end were part of a continuous dream and the bridge portrays the banal reality of waking life. The words also go along with the initial concept of the album, which was to be largely composed of lyrics reminiscent of their youth, as was the case for “Penny Lane” and “Strawberry Fields Forever.”
I’d love to turn you on

“This was the time of Tim Leary’s ‘Turn on, tune in, drop out,’” McCartney recalled, “and we wrote ‘I’d love to turn you on.’ John and I gave each other a knowing look: ‘Uh-huh, it’s a drug song. You know that, don’t you?’ Yes, but at the same time, our stuff is always very ambiguous and ‘turn you on’ can be sexual so … c'mon!” The BBC didn’t appreciate the wordplay. “We have listened to this song over and over again,” a spokesman said in 1967. “And we have decided that it appears to go just a little too far, and could encourage a permissive attitude to drug-taking.”

To “turn on” is to realize all of your potential via a psychedelic or other mystical experience.

As Lennon told Playboy:

Paul’s contribution was the beautiful little lick in the song ‘I’d love to turn you on.’ I had the bulk of the song and the words, but he contributed this little lick floating around in his head that he couldn’t use for anything. I thought it was a damn good piece of work.

Found my way downstairs and drank a cup
 And looking up I noticed I was late
 Found my coat and grabbed my hat

McCartney explains:

It was just me remembering what it was like to run up the road to catch a bus to school, having a smoke and going into class. It was a reflection of my schooldays. I would have a Woodbine, somebody would speak and I’d go into a dream.

It’s not mentioned what the narrator is actually drinking out of the cup. However, considering the fact that it’s written by an Englishman, born and raised in England, it can be assumed that he is drinking a cup of tea.

And though the holes were rather small
 They had to count them all
 Now they know how many holes it takes to fill the Albert Hall

Said Lennon:


There was still one word missing in that verse when we came to record. I knew the line had to go ‘Now they know how many holes it takes to… something, the Albert Hall.’ It was a nonsense verse really, but for some reason I couldn’t think of the verb. What did the holes do to the Albert Hall?

It was Terry [Doran, a former car dealer and friend of Brian Epstein’s who later became head of Apple Music] who said ‘fill’ the Albert Hall. And that was it. Perhaps I was looking for that word all the time, but couldn’t put my tongue on it. Other people don’t necessarily give you a word or a line, they just throw in the word you’re looking for anyway.
